title: A Study of Open Source Evaluation Tools
description:
For my final thesis project at the Blekinge Institute of Technology (BTH), my teammate and I collaborated with the Web/Mobile team at the IT Services Office (ID) at Bern University. We explored a selection of open-source web accessibility evaluation tools and investigated how easily they could be integrated into a CI/CD environment. The study focused on assessing the effectiveness of these tools in detecting WCAG violations within a CI/CD pipeline. The tools selected for our research included Asqatasun, Deque Systems’ Axe-Core CLI, Squiz Labs’ HTML_CodeSniffer, and IBM’s Equal Access Accessibility Checker.

To conduct a thorough evaluation, we developed a test website specifically designed with a set number of Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) violations. The findings of our study provided valuable insights that enabled the Web/Mobile team to rethink and enhance their CI/CD pipeline for better accessibility compliance.

title: Data Analysis with Python and Streamlit
description: This project was part of a Mathematical Modelling course. I used Python, along with libraries such as pandas and scipy, to analyze sunshine duration data for Stockholm, Karlskrona, and Gothenburg. Additionally, I utilized streamlit.io to create interactive visualizations, allowing for clear and intuitive presentation of the data and results.

title: Electric Scooter App
description:
As part of the Software Development in Virtual Teams course, my three teammates and I collaborated to create a responsive web application tailored for electric scooter users. Our project involved addressing a set of requirements provided by a fictional client, with a particular emphasis on performance. To showcase our application’s capabilities, we conducted a presentation at the end of the project that included a simulation demonstrating its functionality with a few thousand users.

In this project, I assumed the role of DevOps Engineer, overseeing the management of our GitHub repository. Additionally, I contributed to the frontend development of the application.

title: Single Page Application for Mobile Devices
description: This project was completed within the framework of the course Web Applications for Mobile Devices, and focused on responsive design. The application provides users with real-time information about train delays within Sweden, utilizing data accessed through the Swedish Transportation Administration (Trafikverket) API. Developed as a single-page application, the project was built using JavaScript and NodeJS with Express.

title: Web Application using Vue and Sockets
description: This team project was part of the JavaScript-based Web Frameworks course, which focused on gaining proficiency with web frameworks. The application provides users with up-to-date information on train traffic across Sweden, pulling data from the Swedish Transportation Administration (Trafikverket) API. This web application was developed with JavaScript, Vue and NodeJS Express. For real-time updates of train delays we used socket.io, a tool which provides a bi-directional communication channel between a client and a server.

title: Client website
description: This project was part of the Technical Web Design and Usability course, where I developed a web application for a fictional client—in this case, my younger brother, an aspiring musician. The course emphasized accessible and user-friendly design, allowing me to apply key principles such as hierarchy, composition, and depth. I created two versions of the website, offering both light and dark modes to enhance usability and cater to different user preferences.
